awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Expanding the repertoire of chemical tools to study and characterize bacterial Gcn5-related N-acetyltransferase functions
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research in Undergraduate Institutions award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program funds Dr. Misty L. Kuhn from San Francisco State University (SFSU) and Dr. Daniel P. Becker from Loyola University Chicago to create biochemical tools to study enzymes in the family of Gcn5-related N-acetyltransferase (GNAT) proteins of unknown function from the soil microorganism, Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Specifically, these tools are used in combination with structure determinations via X-ray crystallography to gain a greater understanding of how molecules bind to GNATs. Since relatively little is known about the structure/function relationship of GNATs from P. aeruginosa, this work fills this gap in knowledge. Determining these functions is important because human welfare depends on healthy agriculture.  This project enhances the research infrastructure at SFSU by establishing its first protein crystallization resource and increasing the repertoire of sophisticated biochemistry skills of underrepresented minority and disadvantaged undergraduate students.
 
The goal of this project is to improve the functional annotation of P. aeruginosa GNATs of unknown function using a combination of protein X-ray crystallography, molecular modeling, organic synthesis, and enzymology. The architecture of the acceptor site of several GNAT proteins are probed using biochemical tools and X-ray crystallography. Active site residues that are critical for catalysis and substrate specificity are identified and tested using molecular modeling, site-directed mutagenesis, and enzyme kinetics. The results of this project provides the foundational knowledge to categorize experimentally uncharacterized members of the GNAT family and improve computational functional annotation of GNATs of unknown function.

por.por_cntn:
Enzymes perform nearly all of the chemical reactions of life, from bacteria through human beings, Therefore, it is critical that we advance in our understanding of how enzymes recognize their substrates and how they function mechanistically. This NSF grant for fundamental research has enabled our team to study members of a vast superfamily of enzymes, the GNATs, which span all realms of life and perform a variety of tasks in life. Enzymes in the Gcn5-related N-acetyltransferase (GNAT) superfamily are widespread in nature and are employed in all domains of life and are critically involved in many cellular processes, for example, GNATs acetylate aminoglycoside antibiotics, amino acids, polyamines, peptides, vitamins, catecholamines, and large macromolecules including proteins. In addition to playing a key role in anabolic and catabolic pathways, they are involved in metabolism of xenobiotic substances and play a role in antibiotic resistance. Furthermore, GNATs also have the potential to be engineered to construct tools for chemical synthesis that are more selective and more sustainable.  Therefore GNATs are worthy of dedicated study in terms of how they recognize their substrates and how the operate mechanistically. Yet, relatively few GNAT enzymes have been structurally characterized, thus there is a paucity of information known about how these enzymes recognize their diverse substrates, and even how they function mechanistically. As acetyl transferases, their job is to transfer the very small acetyl group comprised of only six atoms, but this tiny fragment modulates biochemical pathways including through controlling charge, which provides powerful attractive or repulsive forces over larger distances, and changes the reactivity of groups surround the charge in biomolecules. Mechanistically, it was assumed that these GNAT enzymes operate using a general acid/base mechanism. However, we have demonstrated kinetically, employing chemical tools that we have designed and synthesized, that these enzymes can also operate with a hybrid "ping-pong" mechanism, wherein the acetyl group is first transferred from a donor to the enzyme, then to the substrate, rather than directly from the donor to the substrate. To shed further light on these enzyme mechanisms, we employed computer-aided docking experiments, and we developed new tools for visualizing complex data sets and drawing inferences of key molecular interactions.  This work has enabled the training of a number undergraduate, Master?s level, and Ph.D. students in the STEM fields, specifically in biochemistry, synthetic organic chemistry, and in computer modeling. These students have been intimately involved in all aspects of the work supported by this grant.
